title: Executive Order 14110
content:
{{Short description|American presidential directive}}

{{Infobox U.S. presidential document
| type = executive order
| longtitle = Safe, Secure, and Trustworthy Development and Use of Artificial Intelligence
| executiveorder = 14110
| signedpresident = Joe Biden
| signeddate = October 30, 2023
| documentnumber = 2023-24283
| summary = Creates a national approach to governing artificial intelligence.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-10-30 |title= FACT SHEET: President Biden Issues Executive Order on Safe, Secure, and Trustworthy Artificial Intelligence |url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2023/10/30/fact-sheet-president-biden-issues-executive-order-on-safe-secure-and-trustworthy-artificial-intelligence/ |access-date=2023-11-12 |website=The White House |language=en-US}}</ref>
}}

'''Executive Order 14110''', titled '''Executive Order on Safe, Secure, and Trustworthy Development and Use of Artificial Intelligence''' (sometimes referred to as "'''Executive Order on Artificial Intelligence'''"<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-11-01 |title=OMB Releases Implementation Guidance Following President Biden's Executive Order on Artificial Intelligence {{!}} OMB |url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/omb/briefing-room/2023/11/01/omb-releases-implementation-guidance-following-president-bidens-executive-order-on-artificial-intelligence/ |access-date=2023-11-25 |website=The White House |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Wu |first=Tim |date=2023-11-07 |title=Opinion {{!}} In Regulating A.I., We May Be Doing Too Much. And Too Little. |language=en-US |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/11/07/opinion/biden-ai-regulation.html |access-date=2023-11-25 |issn=0362-4331 |quote="When President Biden signed his sweeping executive order on artificial intelligence last week..."}}</ref>) is the 126th [[executive order]] signed by U.S. President [[Joe Biden]]. Signed on October 30, 2023, the order defines the administration's policy goals regarding [[Artificial_intelligence|artificial intelligence (AI)]], and orders executive agencies to take actions pursuant to these goals. The order is considered to be the most comprehensive piece of governance by the United States regarding AI.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web |author=Tate Ryan-Mosley |author2=Melissa Heikkilä |date=2023-10-30 |title=Three things to know about the White House's executive order on AI |url=https://www.technologyreview.com/2023/10/30/1082678/three-things-to-know-about-the-white-houses-executive-order-on-ai/ |website=MIT Technology Review}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite news |last1=Lima |first1=Cristiano |last2=Zakrzewski |first2=Cat |date=2023-10-30 |title=Biden Signs AI Executive Order, the Most Expansive Regulatory Attempt Yet |newspaper=The Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2023/10/30/biden-artificial-intelligence-executive-order/ |access-date=2023-11-12}}</ref> 

Policy goals outlined in the executive order pertain to promoting competition in the AI industry, preventing AI-enabled threats to civil liberties and national security, and ensuring U.S. global competitiveness in the AI field.<ref name=":0" /> The executive order requires a number of major federal agencies to create dedicated "chief artificial intelligence officer" ([[chief AI officer]]) positions within their organizations.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web |last1=Alder |first1=Madison |last2=Heilweil |first2=Rebecca |date=2023-11-21 |title=Aronson takes chief AI officer position at NSF as agencies begin work on Biden executive order |url=https://fedscoop.com/aronson-takes-chief-ai-officer-position-at-nsf-as-agencies-begin-work-on-biden-executive-order/ |access-date=2023-11-28 |website=FedScoop |language=en-US}}</ref> 

== Background ==
The drafting of the order was motivated by the rapid pace of development in [[Generative_artificial_intelligence|generative AI]] models in the 2020s, including the release of [[large language model]] [[ChatGPT]].<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Leffer |first=Lauren |date=2023-10-31 |title=Biden's Executive Order on AI Is a Good Start, Experts Say, but Not Enough |url=https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/bidens-executive-order-on-ai-is-a-good-start-experts-say-but-not-enough/ |magazine=Scientific American |access-date=2023-11-12}}</ref> Executive Order 14110 is the third executive order dealing explicitly with AI, with two AI-related executive orders being signed by then-President [[Donald Trump]].<ref>{{Cite web |date=2019-02-14 |title=Maintaining American Leadership in Artificial Intelligence |url=https://www.federalregister.gov/d/2019-02544 |website=Federal Register |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2020-12-08 |title=Promoting the Use of Trustworthy Artificial Intelligence in the Federal Government |url=https://www.federalregister.gov/d/2020-27065 |website=Federal Register |language=en-US}}</ref> 

The development of AI models without policy safeguards has raised a variety of concerns among experts and commentators. These range from future [[Existential risk from artificial general intelligence|existential risk]] from [[Artificial general intelligence|advanced AI models]] to immediate concerns surrounding current technologies' ability to disseminate [[misinformation]], enable [[Algorithmic discrimination|discrimination]], and undermine [[national security]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Leffer |first=Lauren |title=Biden's Executive Order on AI Is a Good Start, Experts Say, but Not Enough |url=https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/bidens-executive-order-on-ai-is-a-good-start-experts-say-but-not-enough/ |access-date=2023-11-29 |website=Scientific American |language=en}}</ref> 

In August 2023, [[Arati Prabhakar]], the director of the [[Office of Science and Technology Policy]], indicated that the White House was expediting its work on executive action on AI.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Groll |first=Elias |date=2023-08-12 |title=White House is fast-tracking executive order on artificial intelligence |url=https://cyberscoop.com/white-house-executive-order-artificial-intelligence/ |access-date=2023-11-25 |website=CyberScoop |language=en-US}}</ref> A week prior to the executive order's unveiling, Prabhakar indicated that [[Office of Management and Budget]] (OMB) guidance on the order would be released "soon" after.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Krishan |first=Nihal |date=2023-10-26 |title=OSTP's Arati Prabhakar says OMB guidance on AI to be released 'soon' after AI executive order |url=https://fedscoop.com/ostps-arati-prabhakar-says-omb-guidance-on-ai-to-be-released-soon-after-ai-executive-order/ |access-date=2023-11-25 |website=FedScoop |language=en-US}}</ref>

== Policy goals and provisions ==
[[File:WH-AI.jpg|thumb|White House graphic listing the provisions of the executive order]]
The order has been characterized as an effort for the United States to capture potential benefits from AI while mitigating risks associated with AI technologies.<ref>{{Cite news |last1=Kang |first1=Cecilia |last2=Sanger |first2=David E. |date=2023-10-30 |title=Biden Issues Executive Order to Create A.I. Safeguards |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/10/30/us/politics/biden-ai-regulation.html |access-date=2023-11-12}}</ref> Upon signing the order, Biden stated that AI technologies were being developed at "warp speed", and argued that to "realize the promise of AI and avoid the risk, we need to govern this technology".<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-10-30 |title=Biden wants to move fast on AI safeguards and signs an executive order to address his concerns |url=https://apnews.com/article/biden-ai-artificial-intelligence-executive-order-cb86162000d894f238f28ac029005059 |access-date=2023-11-25 |website=AP News |language=en}}</ref> 

Policy goals outlined by the order include the following:<ref name=":0">{{Cite web |title=Key Takeaways from the Biden Administration Executive Order on AI |website=EY |author=Bridget Neill |author2=John D. Hallmark |author3=Richard J. Jackson |author4=Dan Diasio |url=https://www.ey.com/en_us/public-policy/key-takeaways-from-the-biden-administration-executive-order-on-ai |date=2023-10-31 |access-date=2023-11-12 |language=en-US}}</ref>
* Promoting competition and innovation in the AI industry
* Upholding civil and labor rights and protecting consumers and their privacy from AI-enabled harms
* Specifying federal policies governing procurement and use of AI
* Developing [[Digital_watermarking|watermarking]] systems for AI-generated content and warding off [[intellectual property theft]] stemming from the use of generative models
* Maintaining the nation's place as a global leader in AI

== Impact on agencies ==

=== Creation of chief AI officer positions ===
The executive order requires a number of large federal agencies to appoint a chief artificial intelligence officer, with a number of departments having already appointed a relevant officer prior to the order. In the days following the order, news publication ''FedScoop'' confirmed that the [[General Services Administration]] (GSA) and the [[United States Department of Education]] appointed relevant [[Chief AI officer|chief AI officers]]. The [[National Science Foundation]] (NSF) also confirmed it had elevated an official to serve as its [[chief AI officer]].<ref name=":1" />

=== Department responsibilities ===
Under the executive order, the [[United States Department of Homeland Security|Department of Homeland Security]] (DHS) will be responsible for developing AI-related security guidelines, including cybersecurity-related matters. The DHS will also work with private sector firms in sectors including the [[energy industry]] and other "critical infrastructure" to coordinate responses to AI-enabled security threats.<ref>{{Cite web |last1=Gilmer |first1=Ellen M. |last2=Riley |first2=Tonya |date=2023-11-27 |title=AI Goals Stretch Homeland Agency's Resources, Privacy Safeguards |url=https://news.bgov.com/bloomberg-government-news/ai-goals-stretch-homeland-agencys-resources-privacy-safeguards |access-date=2023-11-28 |website=Bloomberg Law |language=en}}</ref> Executive Order 14110 mandated the [[United States Department of Veterans Affairs|Department of Veterans Affairs]] to launch an AI technology competition aimed at reducing [[occupational burnout]] among healthcare workers through AI-assisted tools for routine tasks.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Nihill |first=Caroline |date=2023-10-31 |title=VA launches tech sprint for health care innovation required by AI executive order |url=https://fedscoop.com/va-launches-tech-sprint-required-by-ai-executive-order/ |access-date=2023-11-28 |website=FedScoop |language=en-US}}</ref> 

The order also mandates the [[United States Department of Commerce|Department of Commerce]]'s [[National Institute of Standards and Technology]] (NIST) to develop a [[generative artificial intelligence]]-focused resource to supplement the existing AI Risk Management Framework.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Alder |first=Madison |date=2023-11-02 |title=NIST seeks participants for new artificial intelligence consortium |url=https://fedscoop.com/nist-seeks-ai-consortium-participants/ |access-date=2023-11-29 |website=FedScoop |language=en-US}}</ref> 

== Analysis ==
[[File:President Joe Biden drops by a meeting with Vice President Kamala Harris and AI CEO’s on May 4, 2023 in the Roosevelt Room of the White House - P20230504AS-0693.jpg|thumb|President Biden visiting a meeting held by Vice President [[Kamala Harris]] alongside CEOs of AI companies on May 4, 2023]]
The executive order has been described as most comprehensive piece of governance by the United States government pertaining to AI.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3" /> Earlier in 2023 prior to the signing of the order, the Biden administration had announced a Blueprint for an AI Bill of Rights, and had secured non-binding AI safety commitments from major tech companies. The issuing of the executive order comes at a time in which lawmakers including Senate Majority Leader [[Chuck Schumer]] have pushed for legislation to regulate AI in the [[118th United States Congress]].<ref name=":4">{{Cite web |last=Morrison |first=Sara |date=2023-10-31 |title=President Biden's new plan to regulate AI |url=https://www.vox.com/technology/2023/10/31/23939157/biden-ai-executive-order |access-date=2023-11-29 |website=Vox |language=en}}</ref> 

According to [[Axios (website)|''Axios'']], despite the wide scope of the executive order, it notably does not touch upon a number of AI-related policy proposals. This includes proposals for a "licensing regime" to government advanced AI models, which has received support from industry leaders including [[Sam Altman]]. Additionally, the executive order does not seek to prohibit 'high-risk' uses of AI technology, and does not aim to mandate that tech companies release information surrounding AI systems' training data and models.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Heath |first=Ryan |date=2023-11-01 |title=What's in Biden's AI executive order — and what's not |url=https://www.axios.com/2023/11/01/unpacking-bidens-ai-executive-order |access-date=2023-11-28 |website=Axios}}</ref> 

== Reception ==

=== Political and media reception ===
The editorial board of the ''[[Houston Chronicle]]'' described the order as a "first step toward protecting humanity".<ref>{{Cite web |last=Houston Chronicle Editorial Board |date=2023-11-03 |title=Biden's AI executive order is a first step toward protecting humanity (Editorial) |url=https://www.houstonchronicle.com/opinion/editorials/article/biden-executive-order-artificial-intelligence-18462334.php |access-date=2023-11-25 |website=Houston Chronicle |language=en}}</ref> The issuing of the order received praise from [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] members of Congress, including Senator [[Richard Blumenthal]] (D-[[Connecticut|CT]]) and Representative [[Ted Lieu]] (D-[[California|CA]]).<ref>{{Cite web |last= |first= |date=2023-11-01 |title=Biden's Executive Order Ensures Safe, Secure AI: Reactions |url=https://www.miragenews.com/bidens-executive-order-ensures-safe-secure-ai-1114429/ |access-date=2023-11-25 |website=Mirage News |language=en-AU}}</ref> Representative [[Don Beyer]] (D-[[Virginia|VA]]), who leads the House AI Caucus, praised the order as a "comprehensive strategy for responsible innovation", while arguing that Congress must take initiative to pass legislation on AI.<ref name=":4" />

The draft of the order received criticism from [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] Senator [[Ted Cruz]] (R-[[Texas|TX]]), who described it as creating "barriers to innovation disguised as safety measures".<ref>{{Cite web |last=Chatterjee |first=Mohar |date=2023-10-30 |title=White House offers a new strategy for AI — and picks new fights |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2023/10/30/biden-ai-tech-industry-policy-00124185 |access-date=2023-11-25 |website=POLITICO |language=en}}</ref>

=== Public reception ===
Polling from the AI Policy Institute showed that 69% of all voters support the executive order, while 15% oppose it. Breaking it down by party, support was at 78% for democrats, 65% for independents, and 64% for Republicans.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Unpacking the President's AI Executive Order |url=https://www.cmswire.com/digital-experience/bidens-ai-executive-order-balancing-the-potential-and-the-pitfalls/ |access-date=2024-07-25 |website=CMSWire.com |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-10-30 |title=Vast Majority of US voters of All Political Affiliations Support President Biden's Executive Order on AI - AI Policy Institute |url=https://theaipi.org/poll-biden-ai-executive-order-10-30/ |access-date=2024-07-25 |language=en-US}}</ref> 

=== Industry reception ===
The executive order received strong criticism from the [[United States Chamber of Commerce|Chamber of Commerce]] as well as tech industry groups including [[NetChoice]] and the [[Software and Information Industry Association]], all of which count "[[Big Tech]]" companies [[Amazon (company)|Amazon]], [[Meta Platforms|Meta]], and [[Google]] as members. Representatives from the organizations argued that the executive order threatens to hinder private sector innovation.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Krishan |first=Nihal |date=2023-11-09 |title=Tech groups push back on Biden AI executive order, raising concerns that it could crush innovation |url=https://fedscoop.com/tech-groups-push-back-on-biden-ai-executive-order-raising-concerns-that-it-could-crush-innovation/ |access-date=2023-11-29 |website=FedScoop |language=en-US}}</ref>

=== Civil society reception ===
According to ''[[CNBC]]'', a number of leaders of advocacy organizations praised the executive order for its provisions on "AI fairness", while simultaneously urging congressional action to strengthen regulation. [[Maya Wiley]], president and CEO of the [[Leadership Conference on Civil and Human Rights]], praised the order while urging Congress to take initiative to "ensure that innovation makes us more fair, just, and prosperous, rather than surveilled, silenced, and stereotyped". A representative from the [[American Civil Liberties Union]] (ACLU) praised provisions of the order centered on combating AI-enabled discrimination, while also voiced concern over sections of the order focused on law enforcement and national security.<ref>{{Cite web |last1=Feiner |first1=Lauren |last2=Field |first2=Hayden |date=2023-11-02 |title=Biden's AI order didn't go far enough to address fairness, but it's a good first step, advocates say |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2023/11/02/biden-ai-executive-order-industry-civil-rights-labor-groups-react.html |access-date=2023-11-29 |website=CNBC |language=en}}</ref>
